Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Darkling?

On the first turn, all Darklings have a 50% chance of using Nip and a 50% chance of using Harden. The middle Darkling continues this pattern afterwards; it cannot use Chomp.

After the first turn, the outer 2 Darklings have a 30% chance of using Nip, 40% chance of using Chomp and 30% chance of using Harden.

Harden cannot be used twice in a row, Chomp cannot be used twice in a row and Nip cannot be used three times in a row.

After the HP of a Darkling reaches 0, the Darkling can no longer be targeted and Regrow will interrupt its current intent. It will use Reincarnate on the next turn. 

Name: Nip, Intent: , Effect: Deal D* damage., Asc 2+: Deal D* + 2 damage., Asc 17+: Deal D* + 2 damage.
Name: Chomp, Intent: , Effect: Deal 8 x 2 damage., Asc 2+: Deal 9 x 2 damage., Asc 17+: Deal 9 x 2 damage.
Name: Harden, Intent: , Effect: Gain 12Block., Asc 2+: Gain 12Block., Asc 17+: Gain 12Blockand 2Strength.
Name: Reincarnate, Intent: , Effect: Revives with 50% HP., Asc 2+: Revives with 50% HP., Asc 17+: Revives with 50% HP.
Name: Regrow, Intent: , Effect: Does nothing., Asc 2+: Does nothing., Asc 17+: Does nothing.
*D is chosen between 7 and 11 at the beginning of the battle.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Notes' of Darkling?

Kill effects that work on minions do have their kill effect on all Darklings regardless of whether it is the last Darkling (e.g. Sunder). However, fatal Kill effects that do not work on minions (i.e. Feed, Ritual Dagger, Lesson Learned, Hand of Greed) only work if you kill the final Darkling.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Gremlins?

In general, it is best to focus on killing any Sneaky Gremlins first, followed by Fat Gremlins, then Shield Gremlins, and finally Mad Gremlins. If a Gremlin Wizard is present, start focusing on him as soon as is necessary to kill him before he uses Ultimate Blast.
Sneaky Gremlins deal the most direct damage, and should be dealt with on the first turn if possible, before they can be protected by a Shield Gremlin and before a Fat Gremlin can weaken you.
Fat Gremlins apply  Weak, which can make killing the other gremlins more difficult, so they should often be dealt with next.
Shield Gremlins will only deal damage to you if they have no allies left to protect. Thus, it is good to kill them after the high priority targets have been dealt with, but before every other gremlin has been killed. You may need to adjust your priorities based on which gremlins the Shield Gremlin chooses to protect. It may be good to attack the Shield Gremlin first if a Gremlin Wizard is present, as the Shield Gremlin may interfere with killing the Gremlin Wizard quickly.
Angry Gremlins do the least damage initially, but their damage will increase as you attack them. Thus, it is best to  Block their attacks for the first few rounds until you can afford to focus on them and kill them quickly.
Gremlin Wizards are a bit trickier to deal with. While they only attack once every three turns, their damage can be difficult to  Block in Act 1. Ideally, you should kill them before they get a chance to use Ultimate Blast, which may require focusing on them before other lower priority gremlins.

Shield Gremlins will only deal damage to you if they have no allies left to protect. Thus, it is good to kill them after the high priority targets have been dealt with, but before every other gremlin has been killed. You may need to adjust your priorities based on which gremlins the Shield Gremlin chooses to protect. It may be good to attack the Shield Gremlin first if a Gremlin Wizard is present, as the Shield Gremlin may interfere with killing the Gremlin Wizard quickly.
Angry Gremlins do the least damage initially, but their damage will increase as you attack them. Thus, it is best to  Block their attacks for the first few rounds until you can afford to focus on them and kill them quickly.
Gremlin Wizards are a bit trickier to deal with. While they only attack once every three turns, their damage can be difficult to  Block in Act 1. Ideally, you should kill them before they get a chance to use Ultimate Blast, which may require focusing on them before other lower priority gremlins.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Monsters in Slay the Spire?

Monsters are the ”basic enemies” of Slay the Spire, and landing on their icon on the map will incur a battle with one or more, depending on the floor. When they are defeated, they will drop coins, a selection of three cards, and sometimes a potion . The same monster encounter cannot be fought again in the next two monster encounters (that is, three consecutive monster encounters never contain two identical fights).

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Orb Walker?

The best strategy to defeat the solo Orb Walker is to be very aggressive. Consider blocking if your attacks in hand are subpar. Because of its buff, the Orb Walker can snowball very quickly. As with most heavy-hitters,  Weak can be a very powerful asset to buy you more time. The  Weak Potion is also effective as the three  Weak will lessen damage every single turn, and the Orb Walker always attacks.

In its Event encounter, focusing on one and then the next is typically the best strategy. Area of Effect damage or cards such as Corpse Explosion are also immensely helpful.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Orb Walker?

Though this monster bears resemblance to a Sentry and seems to be man-made, it doesn't have the  Artifact Buff.
The Orb Walker's resemblance to the Repulsor seems to have no clear connection, apart from that they are both robotic monsters.
Two Orb Walkers used to be an Act 3 Elite encounter until it was replaced by the Reptomancer.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Shelled Parasite?

On turn 1, Shelled Parasite has a 50% chance of using Suck and a 50% chance of using Double Strike.

Afterwards, has a 40% chance of using Double Strike, a 40% chance of using Suck, and a 20% chance of using Fell.

Cannot use Double Strike or Suck three times in a row, and cannot use Fell twice in a row.

It is stunned if its  Plated Armor is reduced to zero, interrupting its current intent.

In Ascension 17+, Shelled Parasite always starts with Fell on turn 1.

Name: Double Strike, Intent: , Effect: Deals 6 x 2 damage., Asc 2+: Deals 7 x 2 damage.
Name: Suck, Intent: , Effect: Deals 10 damage, gains HP equal to unblocked damage dealt., Asc 2+: Deals 12 damage, gains HP equal to unblocked damage dealt.
Name: Fell, Intent: , Effect: Deals 18 damage and applies 2Frail., Asc 2+: Deals 21 damage and applies 2Frail.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Shelled Parasite?

Due to Shelled Parasite's ability, it may be a good idea to use a high damage attack first in the turn, then hit as many times as possible once the  Block is broken to lower its total stacks of  Plated Armor. Doing so will make future attacks take more HP from Shelled Parasite.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Snake Plant?

Because of Snake Plant's ability to add an increasing amount of  Block each time it is attacked per turn, it is recommended to use fewer, harder hitting attacks per turn (if possible). Attacks that hit multiple times will repeatedly trigger malleable but the  Block is added all at once after the entire attack.
With its attack being a low damage with multiple hits,  Thorns and  Strength reduction (such as Disarm, Dark Shackles, or Malaise) are invaluable in the fight.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Snecko in Slay the Spire?

Snecko is a Normal Encounter found in Act 2. Its usage of Confused combined with its ability to make the player Vulnerable may make it appear to be a strong encounter, but many higher-cost decks will benefit from the Confused and defeat the snecko easily. Lower cost decks, however, may have a more difficult time.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Snecko?

Because Snecko inflicts  Confused, deck filled with costly cards (such as those using Perfected Strike) will actually benefit from the debuff rather than suffer.
Decks that rely on low-cost cards can instead negate the  Confused debuff with any source of  Artifact or  Orange Pellets.
Decks that rely on low-cost cards can instead negate the  Confused debuff with any source of  Artifact or  Orange Pellets.
 Odd Mushroom is useful in this fight because it makes the  Vulnerable Snecko applies less potent.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Snecko?

The name 'Snecko' is a combination of the words 'Snake' and 'Gecko'.
The move Tail Whip may be a reference to the Pokémon games, in which there exists a move with the same name that lowers your opponent's defense, making them more  Vulnerable.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Spheric Guardian in Slay the Spire?

Spheric Guardian is a Monster found in Acts 2 and 3 of the Spire. Its low HP of 20 is counteracted by its high amounts of Block , which it will continue to build up as the fight continues. In order to ensure its tankiness, it starts with Barricade as a buff and 3 charges of Artifact .

What is 'Pattern' of Spheric Guardian?

Name: Activate, Intent: , Effect: Gain 25Block., Asc 2+: Gain 25Block., Asc 17+: Gain 35Block.
Name: Harden, Intent: , Effect: Deal 10 damage, gain 15Block., Asc 2+: Deal 11 damage, gain 15Block., Asc 17+: Deal 11 damage, gain 15Block.
Name: Attack/Debuff, Intent: , Effect: Deal 10 damage, apply 5Frail., Asc 2+: Deal 11 damage, apply 5Frail., Asc 17+: Deal 11 damage, apply 5Frail.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Spheric Guardian?

Although the constant  Blocking can make this enemy seem like an impenetrable wall,  Poison can be used to ignore it and attack the HP directly, so long as all 3 charges of  Artifact are cleared first.
 Bag of Marbles,  Red Mask, and  Twisted Funnel can strip off 1 stack of  Artifact for each relic.
The  Frail debuff this enemy applies can be very dangerous when combined with the large amounts of damage it can dish out. If you can apply debuffs fast enough, applying a  Weak debuff or using a card such as Disarm can do a great deal to mitigate these attacks.
In contrast, if you have  Turnip or  Orange Pellets, the  Frail debuff can be completely negated. Thus, gaining enough  Block for the enemy's attacks is less challenging.
In contrast, if you have  Turnip or  Orange Pellets, the  Frail debuff can be completely negated. Thus, gaining enough  Block for the enemy's attacks is less challenging.
If this enemy is accompanied by other enemies, it is usually worth killing the other enemies first. While the Spheric Guardian will continue to build  Block, dealing with more than one attack while  Frail can be overwhelming.
If playing as the Defect, a very useful card in this fight is Melter, which will remove the enemy's  Block and deal significant damage, almost effectively ending the fight.
If playing as the Watcher, Judgment will instantly kill it.

The Maw is an Act 3 encounter. Its scaling over time both through buffing and its attacks increasing in intensity combined with its big health pool can make it a threat for decks with poor offense. Its scaling takes a particularly long time to ramp up to dangerous levels, however.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of The Maw?

Always starts with Roar. 

After using Roar or Drool, the Maw has a 50/50 chance of using Slam or Nom its next turn.

After using Slam, the Maw has an 50/50 chance of using Drool or Nom its next turn.

After using Nom, the Maw will always use Drool.

*T is equal to the total number of turns the combat has lasted, divided by 2 and rounded up.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of The Maw?

While large damage cards such as Bludgeon may seem useful for whittling on its large health pool, forms of scaling like Demon Form or Creative AI work just as well, if not better than, large amounts of damage.
 Poison decks supported by Catalyst or that dish out high amounts of  Poison quickly are also effective. However, Noxious Fumes alone is probably not enough to overcome the Maw's scaling attacks.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Book of Stabbing?

Every turn, the Book of Stabbing has an 85% chance of using Multi-Stab and a 15% chance of using Single Stab. Whenever you receive unblocked damage from one of its attacks, a Wound is shuffled into your discard pile.

Cannot use Multi-Stab 3 times in a row. Cannot use Single Stab twice in a row.

Name: Multi-Stab, Intent: , Effect: Deals 6 x N* damage., Ascension 3+: Deals 7 x N* damage., Ascension 18+: Deals 7 x N** damage.
Name: Single Stab, Intent: , Effect: Deals 21 damage., Ascension 3+: Deals 24 damage., Ascension 18+: Deals 24 damage.
*N is equal to 2 plus the number of times Multi-Stab has been previously used in the fight.
**On Ascension 18+, N increments even on the Single Stab attack.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Book of Stabbing?

It is important to try and kill the Book as quickly as possible, because its attacks will only get worse and can become overwhelming.
The Book suffers greatly against  Weak,  Thorns, and  Strength reduction due to its scaling being solely said multi-hit attacks and its lack of ability to apply any kind of debuff on the player to reduce their ability to  Block.
The Ironclad fares fairly well against the Book as he has a lot of powerful  Block cards, can obtain Disarm to permanently reduce the Book's  Strength, and can obtain Clothesline, Intimidate, and Uppercut to apply  Weak.
The Silent is arguably the best character against the Book. Her access to Footwork and multiple cheap  Block cards allow her to easier stack  Block against the Book. Leg Sweep not only grants a huge  Block, but also apply a large number of  Weak. Neutralize and Sucker Punch are cheap attacks that apply  Weak. Piercing Wail can shut down a Multi-Stab attack. Caltrops deals a large damage against Multi-Stab. Lastly, Malaise can potentially shut down the Book for the entirety of the fight.
The Defect has a harder time against the Book as it mainly relies on slowly scaling with Orbs, Creative AI, or Claw. Consider dealing a large amount of damage by invoking  Lightning or  Dark multiple times to finish off the Book quickly. Biased Cognition can also be used to give said Orbs a burst of damage and  Frost an ability to generates a large  Block against the Book.
The Watcher can deal with the Book quite well with her ability to burst it down during Wrath or Divinity using cards with high base damage such as Ragnarok and Wheel Kick. She can also gain a large number of  Block using Mental Fortress, Nirvana, Talk to the Hand, or Wallop. Wave of the Hand can also apply a large number of  Weak in a single use.
The Ironclad fares fairly well against the Book as he has a lot of powerful  Block cards, can obtain Disarm to permanently reduce the Book's  Strength, and can obtain Clothesline, Intimidate, and Uppercut to apply  Weak.
The Silent is arguably the best character against the Book. Her access to Footwork and multiple cheap  Block cards allow her to easier stack  Block against the Book. Leg Sweep not only grants a huge  Block, but also apply a large number of  Weak. Neutralize and Sucker Punch are cheap attacks that apply  Weak. Piercing Wail can shut down a Multi-Stab attack. Caltrops deals a large damage against Multi-Stab. Lastly, Malaise can potentially shut down the Book for the entirety of the fight.
The Defect has a harder time against the Book as it mainly relies on slowly scaling with Orbs, Creative AI, or Claw. Consider dealing a large amount of damage by invoking  Lightning or  Dark multiple times to finish off the Book quickly. Biased Cognition can also be used to give said Orbs a burst of damage and  Frost an ability to generates a large  Block against the Book.
The Watcher can deal with the Book quite well with her ability to burst it down during Wrath or Divinity using cards with high base damage such as Ragnarok and Wheel Kick. She can also gain a large number of  Block using Mental Fortress, Nirvana, Talk to the Hand, or Wallop. Wave of the Hand can also apply a large number of  Weak in a single use.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Elites in Slay the Spire?

Elites are stronger monsters that are marked separately from normal ones on the map. Defeating an elite will grant you a random relic , 25-35 gold , a card reward and add a score bonus. Depending on the strength of one's deck, fighting elites may not always be a good idea, but the relics they grant can be very powerful. The same elite can appear multiple times in an act, but cannot be encountered twice in a row. The Dead Adventurer event completely ignores this. Playing in Ascension Mode will make elites more common, as the Ascension 1 modifier makes them more common. In addition, higher ascension levels will make elites stronger and tougher. Relics that affect elite encounters:  Black Star: Instead of dropping 1 random relic, defeated elites will instead drop 2 random relics.  Sling of Courage: The player will start each elite combat with 2 Strength.  Preserved Insect: All enemies found in elite rooms will start combat with 25% less HP.  Slaver's Collar: During Boss and Elite combats, gain Energy at the start of your turn. With the exception of Black Star , these relics also work in the Dead Adventurer fight and the second fight in The Colosseum .

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Elite Buffs' of Elites?

After unlocking Act 4, until the Emerald Key is obtained, one of the elites in each Act will appear as a burning elite icon. This 'super elite' will receive one of the following buffs, and it will drop the Emerald Key when defeated.

(Act number + 1) increase in  Strength.
+25% max HP.
(Act number*2 + 2)  Metallicize.
(Act number*2 + 1)  Regenerate.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Giant Head in Slay the Spire?

Giant Head is an Act 3 elite encounter. Its high amount of HP and steadily scaling attacks make it a formidable foe for many decks. However, because of the Slow debuff it begins combat with, high-damage decks with the ability to play a decent number of cards each turn will have no problem taking it down.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Giant Head?

50% chance of using Count and 50% chance of using Glare on the first 4 turns. Cannot use Count or Glare three times in a row. From turn 5 onward, always uses It Is Time.

In Ascension 18+, always uses It Is Time from turn 4 onward.

Name: Count, Intent: , Effect: Deals 13 damage., Asc 3+: Deals 13 damage.
Name: Glare, Intent: , Effect: Applies 1Weak., Asc 3+: Applies 1Weak.
Name: It Is Time, Intent: , Effect: Deals 30 + T* damage., Asc 3+: Deals 40 + T* damage.
*T starts at 0 and increases by 5 every time the attack is used, up to 30 additional damage.

Whenever the Giant Head uses one of its first two abilities, it will count down from 5 to 1, reducing the count by 1 each time. (Will say "5", then "4", then "3", then "2", and finally "1."). When the countdown is finished, the Head will start using It Is Time.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Giant Head?

Play all of your non-attack cards first, if possible; the Slow debuff will cause attacks to do more damage if played after several other cards. Also, it is preferable to play attack cards in an increasing order of damage so harder hitting cards can gain higher percentage bonuses.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Gremlin Leader?

When there are 0 other enemies, will have a 75% chance of using Rally! and a 25% chance of using Stab.

When there is 1 other enemy:

If the last move was Encourage, will have a 50% chance of using Rally! and 50% chance of using Stab.

If the last move was Stab, will have a 62.5% chance of using Rally! and a 37.5% chance of using Encourage.

The last move could not have been Rally!, since Rally! results in at least 2 other enemies.

When there's 2 or 3 other enemies, will have 66% chance of using Encourage and a 34% chance of using Stab.

Cannot use the same move twice in a row.

Name: Encourage, Intent: , Effect: All enemies gain 3Strength. All minions gain 6Block., Asc 3+: All enemies gain 4Strength. All minions gain 6Block., Asc 18+: All enemies gain 5Strength. All minions gain 10Block.
Name: Rally!, Intent: , Effect: Summons up to 2 randomGremlins., Asc 3+: Summons up to 2 randomGremlins., Asc 18+: Summons up to 2 randomGremlins.
Name: Stab, Intent: , Effect: Deals 6 x 3 damage., Asc 3+: Deals 6 x 3 damage., Asc 18+: Deals 6 x 3 damage.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Gremlin Leader?

If you lack considerable damage to burst down the Gremlin Leader, killing the gremlins spawned will increase the likelyhood of her not attacking (Rallying and Encouraging instead), hence giving you turns to continue chipping her health, as well as removing their abilities (such as the Fat Gremlin's  Weak). This also means that the new gremlins spawned do not carry the old gremlins'  Strength buffs.
Any minion from this fight (i.e. spawned gremlins or gremlins that come in the fight) will retreat and be defeated if the Gremlin Leader is defeated.
While Gremlin Leader may summon minions continually, it is important to kill Gremlin Wizards; their attacks are very strong. Killing a Fat Gremlin may also help kill the Leader faster due to its  Weak debuff no longer being applied.
Gremlin Leader continually buffs her allies'  Strength, so killing her quickly is important to avoid her attacks from becoming too deadly.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:

The Gremlin Nob is an Elite enemy found primarily in Act 1 . However, one also appears in Act 2 's Colosseum Event alongside a Taskmaster , provided the player opts to fight. Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Gremlin Nob?

With the exception of the first turn, where it has yet to apply  Enrage, playing Skills will make the Gremlin Nob much more threatening. Since most  Block-granting cards are also Skills, it can be worth more to not play them and take the damage instead. Before using a Skill to mitigate damage, consider how much longer the fight might take.
With the Ironclad's Basic deck, the fight is about being as aggressive as possible until the very end. Use Bash to apply  Vulnerable as much as possible, and play every Strike attack you're dealt. When you feel the Nob will only have one turn left to live, it can be beneficial to play a Defend versus a  Skull Bash.  Burning Blood will absorb some of the impact of the fight at the end.
With the Silent's Basic deck, the fight becomes more painful. The objective, however, does not change. Neutralize helps to mitigate some of the damage. Taking 4 or 10 damage should be much more manageable. Otherwise, lay in with Strikes whenever possible.
With the Defect's Basic deck the fight plays out similar to the Silent. Despite the strength gain it may be worth it to cast Zap early in the fight (especially if you traded away your  starting relic) and Dualcast late in the fight. Dualcast often lets you finish him off a whole turn earlier, making the strength gain irrelevant.
With the Watcher's Basic deck, focus on maintaining aggression and play strong offensive cards. It is usually worth to take damage as the Watcher's style of gameplay can deal excessive amounts of damage in a single turn. Playing cards which enable Wrath or Divinity such as Eruption or Blasphemy to deal a large amount of burst damage can easily finish off the Gremlin Nob.
Powers and Potions can both be effective at mitigating damage in place of Skills.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Gremlin Nob?

The Gremlin Nob is a reference to the Ork Nob from Warhammer 40k.
According to the flavor text of the  Gremlin Horn relic, Gremlin Nobs maintain consistent growth from birth to death.
The second fight of the Colosseum event used to contain two Gremlin Nobs. On 17 January 2019 this was changed to one Gremlin Nob and a Taskmaster instead.
The Gremlin Nob wields a skeleton of a creature which is extremely similar to the rat-like rodent infested by the Fungi Beast. However, there are no rodent monsters in the game.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Lagavulin in Slay the Spire?

The Lagavulin is an Elite enemy found only on the first act of the Spire. It hits heavily and consistently, but is found asleep for the first three turns of combat, unless encountered in the Dead Adventurer Event . This allows the player to decide when to start the fight properly, within reason.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Awakening' of Lagavulin?

Lagavulin will start with the unique debuff "Asleep", as well as a  Metallicize buff, preventing it from taking any action, but granting it 8  Block at the start of every turn. Lagavulin will wake up at the end of its 3rd turn or when any HP damage is taken through the  Block, and will lose its  Metallicize buff in the process.

When Lagavulin wakes up by being attacked, it will be stunned for one turn. If Lagavulin wakes up on its own, it will begin the fourth turn unstunned.

Will attack twice, then uses Siphon Soul; repeats this pattern for the entire duration of the fight.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Lagavulin?

Use the three turns before Lagavulin wakes up to prepare for the fight by using Powers and/or using Skills.
Alternatively, it may be more reasonable to deal damage instead of buffs/debuffs if a large amount of damage is possible.
Alternatively, it may be more reasonable to deal damage instead of buffs/debuffs if a large amount of damage is possible.
Try to stay mostly aggressive for the fight; its Siphon Soul ability will gradually make the fight harder which can be lethal.
The Defect can be an easier character to fight against Lagavulin with than the others, as its Focus (which dictates how effective orbs are) will not be decreased by Siphon Soul.
If you have one  Artifact charge when Siphon Soul is used, it will block the dexterity debuff since that is applied first.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Nemesis in Slay the Spire?

The Nemesis is an Elite encounter found in Act 3 . Nemesis is a large ghost-like enemy wearing a six-eyed goat skull similar to the Silent's , and wielding a scythe. Smoke billows from the skull's eye sockets. The main trick of the Nemesis is their use of  Intangible, a buff that reduces all damage dealt to it to 1.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Nemesis?

Has a 50% chance of using Debuff or attacking on the first turn.

Afterwards, has approximately* a 35% chance of using Debuff, 35% chance of attacking and 30% chance of using Scythe.

It cannot use Debuff or Scythe twice in a row, nor can it use Attack three times in a row.

*The exact AI of Nemesis is a bit more complicated, but the numbers are still almost completely accurate.

Name: Debuff, Intent: , Effect: Shuffles 3Burnsinto your discard pile., Asc 3+: Shuffles 3Burnsinto your discard pile., Asc 18+: Shuffles 5Burnsinto your discard pile.
Name: Attack, Intent: , Effect: Deals 6 x 3 damage., Asc 3+: Deals 7 x 3 damage., Asc 18+: Deals 7 x 3 damage.
Name: Scythe, Intent: , Effect: Deals 45 damage., Asc 3+: Deals 45 damage., Asc 18+: Deals 45 damage.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Nemesis?

The Nemesis is  Intangible every other turn starting from the 2nd, giving the fight a clear tempo of attack and defend. The buff switches on/off right after Nemesis acts. All incoming damage (including  Poison and  Thorns) is reduced to 1 during the  Intangible turn. Players should generally avoid attacking while  Intangible is up, but applying  Poison or using power cards is recommended.
Nemesis' attacks do not increase in power through the fight, but without a source of Exhaust the player will eventually be overwhelmed with Burn cards, so they should take care not to let the fight last too long.
The Boot bypasses  Intangible's damage reduction, so all unblocked attack damage dealt will be increased to 5. This is not run-changing, but serves some use in this fight.
Judgment also ignores  Intangible and can finish off a severely damaged Nemesis.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Nemesis?

Its resemblance to the Silent may mean that it is the Silent's "Nemesis", likely related to the text in the Sensory Stone event.
The Pagan imagery of both the Silent and Nemesis hint at ritualistic conflict. Wearing similar ornaments, the Nemesis is revered by the Silent's tribe in some way, possibly a fallen predecessor or mythical enemy.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Sentry?

It is usually a good idea to kill the front or back sentry, to ensure that you never need to block for more than one sentry's damage.
The easiest time against the 3x Sentry elite fight will be in the beginning, before the Discard pile is ever shuffled into the draw pile. Larger decks may end up drawing more useful cards than Dazed, but will also take longer to draw (and so Exhaust) the Statuses.
Attacks that target more than one enemy, such as Whirlwind or Dagger Spray, are very effective against this elite encounter.
In contrast, attacks that apply debuffs, Bash in particular, will not be as useful in this fight due to the sentries'  Artifact buff.
In contrast, attacks that apply debuffs, Bash in particular, will not be as useful in this fight due to the sentries'  Artifact buff.
Fire Breathing is incredibly effective against the sentries and can easily win the fight on its own once the Dazed cards have been shuffled into the draw pile.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Taskmaster?

The large number of Wounds he shuffles in your deck can be very troublesome, especially on higher Ascension levels. If playing as the Ironclad, this can be countered by Evolve and/or Fire Breathing. Other characters can counter the Wounds by exhausting them or using the  Medical Kit relic.
If playing as the Silent, Piercing Wail is extremely useful, as all enemies will attack most turns. For other characters, Dark Shackles has a similar effect.
It may be best to kill the Red Slaver in the back first, so that he can't use his Entangle ability to prevent you from attacking. In addition, the  Vulnerable he applies is very dangerous when 3 enemies are attacking.
After killing the Red Slaver, it may be a good idea to kill the Blue Slaver next, as it applies  Weak, which will actively make your attacks less effective. However, on Ascension 18 and higher, it may be preferable to kill the Taskmaster earlier due to his  Strength gain.
A powerful card that damages all enemies such as Whirlwind, Immolate and Electrodynamics is extremely useful in this fight.

What is the Pattern for Awakened One regarding Phase 1 (Unawakened)?

Always begins with Slash. Has a 25% chance of using Soul Strike and a 75% chance of using Slash every turn. Slash cannot be used three times in a row and Soul Strike cannot be used twice in a row.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Awakened One?

The Awakened One is designed to counter decks that utilize Power cards and decks that are designed to deal massive amounts of damage in one turn due to its Curiosity and Rebirth buffs. If your deck heavily relies on these strategies in Act 3, the fight may be more difficult than normal.

Kill the Cultists as soon as possible as they gain  Strength each turn after the first. The Awakened One itself is straightforward to handle: match your defense to the specific attack and use the rest of your energy to deal damage. Once you lower it to 0 HP, it will become invulnerable until its next turn while removing debuffs like weakened and vulnerable. Use that turn to ramp up your defense and possibly play power cards that were saved, since The Awakened One will immediately use its Dark Echo attack. Surviving Phase 2 is mostly a matter of surviving Dark Echo -- especially the first one, which could catch unsuspecting characters off-guard. Save any exhaust cards that will help speed up this phase (e.g. Terror).

Watch out for Phase 1's Curiosity ability. Whenever you play a Power, the Awakened One will gain 1  Strength (2 in Ascension 19+). This is especially dangerous with the Soul Strike attack, which will use the  Strength bonus four times. Even if you have a Power build, you might want to avoid using them during this phase. Curiosity goes away in Phase 2, so you might want to spam your Powers when the Awakened One enters its invulnerable state between the phases, or as soon as Phase 2 begins.

Use temporary  Strength debuffs (like Piercing Wail) right before killing his first form. The debuff will permanently lower  Strength in Phase 2, but not below 0.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Awakened One?

The Awakened One is the deity that both the Cultists and the Chosen worship.
 Matryoshka and  Eternal Feather reference this boss in their flavor text.
It is known that the Awakened One is the crow god Mazaleth according to the  Bird-Faced Urn's flavor text.
There is a Ritual Dagger stuck in the Awakened One's chest.
The Awakened One may be the end result of a ritual involving a lucky Chosen, as a way to manifest the deity they worship. Evidence to support this theory includes the the humanoid hands and body shape of the Awakened One, the name "Chosen", and the blue feathers that appear to be growing out of the body of the Chosen (in contrast to the Cultists, who appear to be only wearing clothes that mimic feathers). There is also the Ritual Dagger, which was used by worshippers of the deity in The Nest event, signaling that the body that houses the Awakened One was stabbed on purpose as part of a cult ritual.
If you kill the main Awakened One boss without killing the two cultists (both forms, over two turns), the cultists will run away, with the speech bubble "Grr...". Coincidentally (?), this is the same speech bubble the Awakened One uses when they transform.
Although the two Cultists in party with the Awakened One will run away when the Awakened One dies, they are not Minions and cards with the Fatal keyword will trigger when they are killed. This can be relevant if the Awakened One is the first Boss fought in Act 3 on Ascension 20, or if the player will continue to Act 4. Killing the first phase of the Awakened One will not trigger any Fatal effects, but will trigger on death effects such as Sunder.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Bosses in Slay the Spire?

Bosses are incredibly difficult monsters that are encountered at the end of each Act. Compared to both normal monsters and elites , bosses typically sport a much higher health pool, much more damaging attacks, and utilize special gimmicks that either heavily cripple the player's deck or considerably buff themselves. Every boss has a unique portrait visible at the top of the Spire map, which can help plan a deck accordingly. The preceding map location will always be a Rest Site , allowing the player to heal before the fight; the only exception to this is the Corrupt Heart in Act 4 which always has a special elite encounter before it. One boss is fought at the end of each Act. To advance to the next Act, the boss must successfully be defeated. At the end of Act 3 , two bosses are fought in a row at Ascension 20. Upon defeating the Act 1 and Act 2 bosses, the player is rewarded with gold , a choice between three rare cards , a choice between three boss relics , and occasionally, a random potion . The Act 3 and Act 4 bosses do not award the player any consumables or cards. The player is also healed to full health ( 75% of missing health starting at Ascension 5) at the end of every boss battle. Slaying a boss will add 50 points to a run's score . Slaying a boss without taking damage, not including self-damaging cards such as Offering , adds an additional 50 points. Slaying all three bosses without taking any damage adds 200 points and overrides any previous flawlessness bonus. Some relics will activate during boss fights:  Pantograph will heal the player for 25 HP at the start of each boss combat.  Slaver's Collar will give the player an additional Energy at the start of their turn. Conversely, relics such as the Wing Boots cannot be used to skip boss fights, as all paths in an Act lead to the floor that contains the boss. During the Mind Bloom Event in Act 3 , choosing the [I Am War] option starts a fight with a random Act 1 boss for a random rare relic . This boss fight does not add towards the run's score, but does activate the Pantograph and Slaver's Collar relics. The Act 4 boss cannot be fought on the first playthrough of any character minus the Watcher . To fight the Act 4 boss, the player must defeat the Act 3 boss with the Ironclad , the Silent , and the Defect at least once.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the combat pattern of Bronze Orb?

Has a 75% chance of using Stasis, 7.5% chance of using Beam and 17.5% chance of using Support Beam every turn.

After Stasis is used, will now have a 70% chance of using Support Beam and a 30% chance of using Beam every turn. It cannot use the same move 3 times in a row.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Corrupt Heart?

Strength reduction and/or damage reduction is very effective against The Heart, since its Blood Shots only deal 2 damage initially. This includes:
Piercing Wail
Dark Shackles
Disarm
Malaise
 Torii
Piercing Wail
Dark Shackles
Disarm
Malaise
 Torii
Do not use either of the first two cards in this list on a turn where The Heart buffs. It will clear the strength down debuff, then gain back the strength you made it lose from the card, essentially making you give The Heart free strength.
Any source of  Weak will also be extremely valuable against both of The Heart's attacks.
Sources of damage negation such as  Intangible and  Buffer can be very effective against the Echo attack.  Intangible is also reasonably useful against Blood Shots, as it will always lower the damage to 12 (15), whereas  Buffer would only negate 1 (2) of the attacks.
 Incense Burner is a source of  Intangible that can reliably block Blood Shots or Echo on turn two or three, if you end the Spire Shield and Spire Spear fight with it on 3 or 4. Because the attack pattern repeats every three turns, it will activate again on turn 9 or 10, during The Heart's third use of Blood Shots or Echo. Alternatively, it also works to set the relic to 0 or 1 to block the second and fourth cycles.
 Incense Burner is a source of  Intangible that can reliably block Blood Shots or Echo on turn two or three, if you end the Spire Shield and Spire Spear fight with it on 3 or 4. Because the attack pattern repeats every three turns, it will activate again on turn 9 or 10, during The Heart's third use of Blood Shots or Echo. Alternatively, it also works to set the relic to 0 or 1 to block the second and fourth cycles.
Any effect that triggers on-damage or on-attack is very good against The Heart due to it triggering 12 (15) times for each Blood Shots that The Heart does. This includes:
 Thorns
Static Discharge
Flame Barrier
 Self-Forming Clay
 Thorns
Static Discharge
Flame Barrier
 Self-Forming Clay
 Medical Kit can be useful against The Heart, as it will allow you to remove the many statuses it will inflict on you, but beware of its Beat of Death power, as it will trigger whenever you play any card, including curses and statuses.
 Tungsten Rod or After Image can completely negate Beat of Death 1. Both of these, 2 copies of After Image, or gaining  Intangible with either is necessary to negate Beat of Death 2, which is found on Ascension 19+ or applied on The Heart's second Buff action.
Mitigating the debuffs from Debilitate is important to take less damage in the first attack cycle. This includes:
 Artifact, with one stack negating  Vulnerable since it's applied first, and three negating all. Saving an  Ancient Potion is a strong option for this strategy.
 Turnip will prevent  Frail and  Odd Mushroom will reduce the effect of  Vulnerable, so buying the former in shops when possible and fighting the Fungi Beasts in the Hypnotizing Colored Mushrooms event can be worthwhile.
While  Weak isn't a major problem if the goal is to block the first cycle,  Ginger will prevent it, which means that  Frail will be negated by a second stack of  Artifact since it's applied third. This is notable because Panacea+ provides two stacks, and so does an  Ancient Potion combined with  Sacred Bark.
 Clockwork Souvenir and  Orange Pellets, both shop-exclusive relics, provide very reliable ways to deal with these debuffs, so checking the rightmost relic slot in shops, where such relics are always found, for these and purchasing them is a priority.
To help trigger  Orange Pellets specifically on turn two or three, it's important to guarantee playing a power on those turns. This can be done by saving a  Power Potion for the turn or holding a power (especially an Innate or  Bottled one) in your hand by obtaining  Runic Pyramid or playing Well-Laid Plans or Equilibrium to  Retain it.

Because Vault does not affect buffs on enemies, the Invincible damage cap is not reset for the extra turn.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Corrupt Heart?

An early version of this boss, which didn't make it past the playtesting phase around two years before it was released, used to deal 1 blockable damage per second instead of per card played.[1] This would make it the only timing-based gameplay mechanic outside of the Speed Climber Achievement and the Speedster and Lightspeed Scores.
Mental Fortress activates before Beat of Death for every Stance-changing card, except for Indignation, which will activate after.[2]

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Donu and Deca?

Compared to the other Act 3 boss fights, the Donu and Deca fight is a simple but brutal slugfest. Their consistent attack patterns make them easy to predict, but they attack every turn and their damage scales rapidly due to Donu's Circle of Power. Furthermore, their plated armor grants them a deceptive amount of HP over the course of the fight, while their initial Artifact charges grant them a degree of resistance against powerful cards like Bash and Piercing Wail.

Most of the time, you should choose one of the two bosses to focus down before moving on to the other. Decks that cannot out-block the scaling damage from Circle of Power should typically kill Donu as quickly as possible. On the other hand, the Dazes that Deca shuffles into the discard pile can vastly slow down your draw as the fight wears on, particularly for decks lacking in card draw. These decks may prefer to kill Deca first.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Pattern' of Hexaghost?

Starts with Activate, followed by Divider. After this, each of its attacks lights one green flame. Once there are six flames, it will use Inferno, and then snuff out all flames. The attack pattern, and the number of flames on that move, are as follows:

0. Sear
1. Tackle
2. Sear
3. Inflame
4. Tackle
5. Sear
6. Inferno
After it has used its first Inferno attack, Sear will give the player Burn+ card instead of the regular Burn. This deals 4 damage instead of 2.

Name: Activate, Intent: , Effect: Nothing.
Name: Divider, Intent: , Effect: Deals (H+1) x 6 damage. H = (Current Player HP divided by 12), rounded down.
Name: Inferno, Intent: , Effect: Deals 2 x 6 damage, shuffles 3Burninto the discard pile. Upgrades allBurn.
Name: Sear, Intent: , Effect: Deals 6 damage, shuffles aBurninto the discard pile.
Name: Tackle, Intent: , Effect: Deals 5 x 2 damage.
Name: Inflame, Intent: , Effect: Gains 2Strengthand 12Block.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Slime Boss?

Slam hits for quite a bit of damage, so try and force him to split by his 3rd turn by dealing 70+ total damage, or use  Weak and/or a lot of  Block.
Since the slimes left after split have health equal the boss's, it's a good idea to try to get it as far below half health as you can in one turn, so the new slimes have less health and are easier to deal with. The same strategy applies to the smaller slimes when they split.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Trivia' of Slime Boss?

The name “Slime Boss” is a parody of “Crime Boss” due to the fact that this boss has a Mafia-style hat and also splits into other slimes, a reference to the elusive and neverending nature of mob families.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the Pattern for The Champ regarding Phase 1?

Always uses Taunt every 4 turns. On all other turns, has:

15% chance to Defensive Stance
15% chance to Gloat
25% chance to Face Slap
45% chance to Heavy Slash
Moves cannot be used twice in a row: If the previous move would be repeated, the move that comes after it in the list above is selected instead. For example, if the previous move was Gloat, there is now a 0% chance of Gloat and a 40% chance of Face Slap with all the other probabilities unchanged.

If Heavy Slash is used, its probability chance is added to Face Slap instead of Defensive Stance.

On Ascension 19+, he will use Defensive Stance instead of Gloat. Defensive Stance can be cast at most twice per battle and subsequent casts are instead Gloats, regardless of ascension.

When HP drops below 50%, he will use Anger next turn and enter Phase 2.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the Pattern for The Champ regarding Phase 2?

After using Anger, will use Execute immediately.

For the next two turns, selects random moves (same exact behavior as in Phase 1), then Executes again. Repeats this pattern (2 random moves, then Execute).

Name: Defensive Stance, Intent: , Effect: Gains 15Blockand 5Metallicize.
Name: Face Slap, Intent: , Effect: Deals 12 damage, applying 2Frailand 2Vulnerable.
Name: Taunt, Intent: , Effect: Applies 2Weakand 2Vulnerable.
Name: Heavy Slash, Intent: , Effect: Deals 16 damage.
Name: Gloat, Intent: , Effect: Gains 2Strength.
Name: Execute, Intent: , Effect: Deals 10 x 2 damage.
Name: Anger, Intent: , Effect: Removes all debuffs, gains 6Strength.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of The Champ?

Once the Champ uses his Phase 2 attacks, his strength will be very high, making his attacks do significantly more damage. Combined with the  Frail and  Vulnerable debuffs, the fight can quickly become very dangerous. Execute is a deadly attack; it can end up dealing damage in the twenties 2 times.

Generally, you want to spend the first half of the fight setting up, and then you want to very quickly kill the Champ once his HP drops below half.

Taunt is used on turn 4. Both Anger and Execute (from Phase 2) will override Taunt, letting you avoid the  Weak debuff if you get his health below half of his max HP on turns 3 or 4. If you cannot burst this quickly (most decks cannot), avoid getting him angry on turns 5 and 6, as the weak effect makes it difficult for you burst properly through Phase 2, and likely means you will eat another Execute.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the Pattern for The Guardian regarding Offensive Mode?

Will always perform the pattern Charging Up, Fierce Bash, Vent Steam, and then Whirlwind. When returning from Defensive Mode, the next attack will be Whirlwind, and then continues the pattern as normal. 

Its Mode Shift status reduces in number equal to health it has lost. Once it reaches 0, it will shift into Defensive Mode, interrupting any previous intentions and instantly changing its intent to Defensive Mode. 

In addition, shifting back to Offensive Mode will add 10 to Mode Shift.

Name: Charging Up, Intent: , Effect: Gains 9 Block.
Name: Fierce Bash, Intent: , Effect: Deals 32 damage.
Name: Vent Steam, Intent: , Effect: Inflicts 2Weakand 2Vulnerable(in that order).
Name: Whirlwind, Intent: , Effect: Deals 5 x 4 damage.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the Pattern for The Guardian regarding Defensive Mode?

Immediately gains 20  Block when shifting to Defensive Mode. Will perform the pattern Defensive Mode, Roll Attack, and Twin Slam. Will lose Sharp Hide when switching to Offensive Mode. Also note that the damage done by Sharp Hide can be blocked, so don't be too afraid to attack.

Sharp Hide works similarly to  Thorns, except it activates when you play attack cards, not when you hit the enemy. For example, using a Twin Strike will activate it only once, and using a Skewer at 0 energy will also activate it once.

Name: Defensive Mode, Intent: , Effect: Gain 3 Sharp Hide.
Name: Roll Attack, Intent: , Effect: Deals 9 damage.
Name: Twin Slam, Intent: , Effect: Deals 8 x 2 damage, removes Sharp Hideand shifts back to Offensive mode.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of The Guardian?

Compared to the other Act 1 bosses, The Guardian is often considered the easiest of them, due to its mechanic that it will always interrupt its intent and change into gaining block upon receiving enough damage. Most decks will have an easy time simply focusing on doing as much direct damage as possible, so it will be interrupted just before it would release a Fierce Bash or Whirlwind. Manage your cards so you will have lots of damage during Offensive Mode and some  Block during Defensive Mode so you don't get damaged as much if you want to attack while it has  Thorns.

Poison will proc mode shift and avoid thorns, and as such is very effective against this boss.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Time Eater?

Unique among enemies, Time Eater is capable of ending the player's turn immediately. The player should take special care to ensure that they can play an appropriate number of cards each turn.
The Time Eater punishes decks that play many cards per turn, such as infinite or Shiv decks, especially hard. If you are relying heavily on this deck type in Act 3, it may be worth reconsidering your strategy.
Playing a consistent number of cards per turn may be useful so that Time Warp does not limit you to a one-card turn. For example, it's usually preferable to play 4 cards, then 5, then 3, rather than 7 cards, then 4, then 1.
The Time Eater punishes decks that play many cards per turn, such as infinite or Shiv decks, especially hard. If you are relying heavily on this deck type in Act 3, it may be worth reconsidering your strategy.
Playing a consistent number of cards per turn may be useful so that Time Warp does not limit you to a one-card turn. For example, it's usually preferable to play 4 cards, then 5, then 3, rather than 7 cards, then 4, then 1.
Try to avoid using low-cost, spammable cards when you can. These cards will quickly increment the Time Warp ability and Time Eater will gain too much strength to be dealt with.
As an example, if you were to play Acrobatics, draw 1 Strike+ and 1 Defend+, and play them both, it would cost 3 Time Warp charges. A single Dash+ would give roughly the same block and damage for the same amount of energy, but only 1 Time Warp charge.
As an example, if you were to play Acrobatics, draw 1 Strike+ and 1 Defend+, and play them both, it would cost 3 Time Warp charges. A single Dash+ would give roughly the same block and damage for the same amount of energy, but only 1 Time Warp charge.
Time Eater can only use Haste once and will always use Haste the turn after falling below half HP. Since Haste erases all debuffs and heals the Time Eater back to half HP, there is no reason to take offensive action once the Time Eater is below half HP unless you can kill the Time Eater in one turn. It is better to play Powers and buff yourself for the remaining battle when possible.
Due to the fact that the heal can be reliably activated, it may be worth ending the turn with Time Warp close to 12 if it lets you get the Time Eater below half HP, as you can safely play only one or two cards next turn while he heals, resetting the timer.
The heal action will remove the debuffs from Piercing Wail and Dark Shackles and their "buffs" (regaining  Strength), causing Time Eater to permanently lose any  Strength it had before.
The debuff cleanse from Haste can be challenging for certain decks, such as slow-ramping Poison decks. Plan accordingly.
Due to the fact that the heal can be reliably activated, it may be worth ending the turn with Time Warp close to 12 if it lets you get the Time Eater below half HP, as you can safely play only one or two cards next turn while he heals, resetting the timer.
The heal action will remove the debuffs from Piercing Wail and Dark Shackles and their "buffs" (regaining  Strength), causing Time Eater to permanently lose any  Strength it had before.
The debuff cleanse from Haste can be challenging for certain decks, such as slow-ramping Poison decks. Plan accordingly.
The Watcher can nullify Time Warp by playing Vault as the twelfth card. The result is the same as if you had normally played a Vault card and the Time Warp counter is reset.
Playing Omniscience as the 12th card (from hand or during an Omniscience chain) can bypass the card limit. However, it must be played as the 12th card, playing Omniscience as the 11th card cannot bypass the card limit unless another Omniscience is selected to be the 12th card play, see Omniscience wiki page for more information.
If the 12th card play triggers a card select menu, and the player uses  Distilled Chaos before closing the menu, then  Distilled Chaos can bypass the card limit before being forced to end the turn (this is especially powerful with Scrying cards since they can manipulate which cards are being played by  Distilled Chaos). Note that if the card draws, then the card draw happens before  Distilled Chaos; The "Disabled confirmation when choosing 1 card" preference setting could stop this from working when there is only 1 card available to choose from. The list of all cards that triggers a card select menu is: Headbutt, Armaments (not upgraded), True Grit (upgraded), Warcry, Burning Pact, Dual Wield, Exhume, Survivor, Dagger Throw, Acrobatics, Prepared, Concentrate, Setup, Nightmare, Hologram, Recycle, Seek, Cut Through Fate, Just Lucky, Third Eye, Foreign Influence, Meditate, Omniscience, Wish, Discovery, Forethought, Purity, Secret Technique, Secret Weapon, Thinking Ahead.

The Watcher's Sensory Stone text implies that her peer went missing and stopped reporting back to their sect about the Spire. Time Eater might be that missing peer of hers.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Interactions' of Anger?

Along with the  Unceasing Top relic, Anger can be used to create a nearly infinite combo without as much deck modification as other such combos.
Cards that exhaust many other cards, such as Second Wind and Fiend Fire, can help this combo approach truly infinite status.
Any other 0-cost cards can be incorporated into this combo. For instance, adding one or more Flex cards can help scale the combo's damage faster, and adding one or more Rage cards can provide block.
Status cards pose a threat to this combo, but can be dealt with using the  Medical Kit relic to Exhaust them.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Mechanics' of Blood for Blood?

Because its cost lowers from lost HP, rather than damage, it is affected by effects like Offering and Combust.
The cost decreases by the number of times you lose HP, not the amount of HP lost.
If this card is created during combat (such as through  Dead Branch,  Attack Potion, or Foreign Influence), it will account for HP lost before it existed, unlike Masterful Stab.
HP loss that is reduced to 0 by an effect such as  Tungsten Rod does not lower the card's cost.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Bludgeon?

Bludgeon features a good energy-damage ratio, with nearly 11 damage per energy before being upgraded, and 14 when after being upgraded. However, its high energy cost means you can not put up a defense without some additional source of energy, and its applications with Double Tap are more limited. Bludgeon is more helpful against the low health of Act 1 enemies, and is very useful for them if obtained early, as it can finish encounters early with no risk for retaliation.  Snecko Eye is great with Bludgeon, as having an average energy cost of 1.5 makes it have much better value.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Double Tap in Slay the Spire?

Double Tap is a Skill card for the Ironclad . It plays the next Attack card this turn a second time, for no Energy . As a Rare card, it can be obtained after defeating a Boss . It is Ironclad's version of Burst and Amplify . Upon upgrade, it will trigger for the 2nd Attack card played in the same turn. The second play is NOT added to your draw or discard pile. The scaling buff from Double Tap (and also from Burst and Amplify ) is the number of cards that will be played twice, not the number of times the card will be played. This means playing multiple Double Taps will add to the number of cards that will be played twice that turn, not make the next card play 3 or more times.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:

The second play will not cost any Energy, but it will trigger any other consequences of playing the card. For example, a Double Tapped Hemokinesis will trigger the self-damage twice.
The second play of a card that costs X energy will use the same value of X as the first.
The second play acts as a separate card. This has interactions including, but not limited to:
Rage.
Shuriken, Kunai, and Pen Nib: Both plays count towards playing Attacks for their benefits. The second play can possibly receive triggered benefits.
Velvet Choker: Both plays count towards the amount of cards played for the turn.
Time Eater's Time Warp power: Both plays increase the counter as usual. If the second attack is the 13th action on his counter, it will NOT occur, unlike Velvet Choker.
Rage.
Shuriken, Kunai, and Pen Nib: Both plays count towards playing Attacks for their benefits. The second play can possibly receive triggered benefits.
Velvet Choker: Both plays count towards the amount of cards played for the turn.
Time Eater's Time Warp power: Both plays increase the counter as usual. If the second attack is the 13th action on his counter, it will NOT occur, unlike Velvet Choker.
The second play happens after the Attack is sent to the draw, discard or Exhaust piles. This has interactions including, but not limited to:
Headbutt: The second play can return the original Headbutt into the deck.
Malleable: Snake Plant receives its armor from Malleable after the first play.

The second play can trigger any Exhaust synergies, but only if the Attack Exhausts when played.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Mechanics' of Dual Wield?

All characteristics of the selected card are copied. When copying a card with altered Energy cost or altered text, such as those related to Madness,  Confused, Rampage, and Blood for Blood, the modifications are also copied.
If the player's hand is full, the copied card(s) is sent to the discard pile.
Copied cards only exist during the combat that Dual Wield is played, and will not carry over after the combat is finished.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Dual Wield?

Any mechanic which creates 0-cost cards that are normally expensive can be very powerful with dual wield as the copies also cost 0. Potions that do this are power, attack and liquid memories. Relics include Mummified Hand and cards include Discovery, Infernal Blade, Madness and more.
Duel Wield can copy powerful self-Exhausting cards like Feed and Pummel so they can be played repeatedly, or copy Powers to stack their effects. Consider discarding the copy instead of playing it, so that it can be copied more when drawn again.
Copies of Searing Blow will remain Upgraded, so Dual Wield works well when creating copies of a highly-Upgraded Searing Blow.
Dual Wield doesn't Exhaust itself, allowing the player to repeatedly copy the same card. By Exhausting undesired cards with True Grit and similar cards, the player can create a deck containing nothing but a single powerful card or combo.
Copying a "Strike" card with Dual Wield increases the power of Perfected Strike. Perfected Strike itself is a "Strike" card, so making copies of Perfected Strike makes them all more powerful.
Prioritize copying key cards as quickly as possible, as having more copies makes it more likely to draw that card and Dual Wield again on future turns.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Update History' of Dual Wield?

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Feed?

The earlier in the run you can acquire Feed, the better.  If you draft Feed, you want to maximize its use by gaining max health from it every combat, and upgrading Feed can allow for even more max health.  It may take a few extra turns to draw Feed when the enemy is close to dying but on almost all non-elite non-boss fights it will be worth it. Feed works well in decks with high  Strength, as the increased damage makes it easier to get land a kill with Feed and trigger its unique effect. Dual Wield can be used in encounters with multiple enemies in order to gain even more max health.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Interactions' of Feed?

If fighting Darklings, then reducing the HP of one of them to 0 does not count as a kill until you have killed the final enemy from the batch. Nor will it count if you defeat the first phase of the Awakened One.

If you have Magic Flower, the Max HP increase does get affected, to a total of 5(6) Max HP.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Notes' of Feed?
There is an achievement ("Ooh Donut!") related to this card, which is gained if Donu is killed by this card.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Interactions' of Feel No Pain?

Ethereal cards Exhaust themselves at the end of the turn, which triggers Feel No Pain. This makes the card a particularly effective counter to accumulated Dazed (Sentries, Chosen), adds flexibility to ethereal attack/skill cards (Carnage, Ghostly Armor), and grants free  block from ethereal curses (Ascender's Bane, Clumsy).
Combining Feel No Pain with True Grit generates high  block for one Energy. This in turn can provide heavy damage for Body Slam.
Corruption synergizes strongly with Feel No Pain, granting a bonus 3-4  block for every 0 Energy skill card played.
Using Fiend Fire with Feel No Pain can eliminate the need to block for the current turn while allowing maximum damage for Fiend Fire.
Multiple copies of Feel No Pain stack, granting the total  Block whenever a card is Exhausted.
Feel No Pain is not affected by  Dexterity or  Frail.

When copying this card (e.g. with Double Tap), the second use of Fiend Fire will deal no damage. The first use will have Exhausted all cards in hand, leaving none to Exhaust for the second.
Effects that can add cards to the hand in between uses (e.g.  Dead Branch, Dark Embrace,  Ink Bottle) can get around this.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Infernal Blade in Slay the Spire?

Infernal Blade is an Uncommon Skill for the Ironclad that generates a random Attack and reduces its cost to 0 for the turn, then Exhausts . If you use Infernal Blade as other character that is not the Ironclad , it will grant a random Attack card of the respective color of that character. For example, if you obtained this card as the Silent , it will grant you a green Attack card. Prismatic Shard does not affect the variety of colors of the card it generated. It however is affected by Run Modifiers , which could potentially allow it to generate an Attack from more than one color of cards pools. Upon upgrade, it becomes free itself. It can only generate a card that is available through shop and rewards with some exceptions. It cannot generate a healing card.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Perfected Strike in Slay the Spire?

Perfected Strike is an Attack card for the Ironclad . It deals 6 damage plus 2 for every card with "Strike" in its name in the player's draw pile, discard pile, and hand. As a Common card, it can be found as a reward after combats. Upgrading Perfected Strike increases the damage bonus for each "Strike" from 2 to 3. The bonus damage is added to the base damage of the card, and all the damage is dealt in one shot, meaning strength bonuses are applied only once and not multiple times. In combat, the first line of the card's text is updated to reflect the additional damage. Each copy of Perfected Strike counts itself as a "Strike". The eligible cards are: Perfected Strike Pommel Strike Strike Twin Strike Wild Strike Swift Strike In game modes where you have access to cards of every color, it additionally counts: The Defect's Strike The Silent's Strike The Watcher's Strike Sneaky Strike Thunder Strike Meteor Strike Windmill Strike

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Interactions' of Reaper?

Because the health restored is based on the damage dealt, anything that increases damage, including  Vulnerable,  Strength buffs, Relics, Stances, and upgrading Reaper will increase the amount of health restored.
Similarly, effects that reduce damage, such as Weak or enemy Buffs, will reduce the health restored.
Similarly, effects that reduce damage, such as Weak or enemy Buffs, will reduce the health restored.
Reaper restores health equal to the HP the enemy loses. For instance, dealing 4 damage to an enemy with 1 HP will only restore one point of health, and blocked damage is not healed.
The heal from Reaper applies after taking damage from  Thorns and  Sharp Hide, and cannot be used to avoid death by these effects.
As a healing card, Reaper cannot be created by Infernal Blade or Metamorphosis.
Due to its long animation requiring the red orbs needing to touch the character, using Reaper as a finishing blow against certain enemies that have fast death animations and/or are in spots farther away from the character can sometimes cause the reward screen to show up and the battle to end before the healing is able to work.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Reaper?

Reaper is a clunky card - not only is it situational, but it's expensive at 2 Energy. When playing a deck with Reaper, take care not to get too greedy. It's easy to make poor plays in the hope that Reaper will restore more health in the future. At the same time, however, Reaper can also be one of the most powerful cards in the entire game. With enough Strength gain, Reaper can gain an incredible amount of health each fight.
In fights with one or two enemies, it's usually advisable to play Reaper as soon as possible to avoid drawing it in the future. With more enemies, you can hold out longer, but be careful - wait too long, and you may need to kill the enemy you had hoped to drain.
In general, you should play Reaper as soon as enemies give you an opening unless you'll lose more HP that turn by using it than by blocking, or you have a reliable way of gaining large amounts of Strength, such as Demon Form or an upgraded Limit Break.
Reaper is generally not worth spending a Smith action to upgrade - it only increases the damage by 1, which usually translates to at most 3-5 extra damage/health.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Synergies' of Reaper?

Reaper performs well with cards that inflict  Vulnerable, which sharply increases the amount of health restored.
Reaper's best friends are  Strength buffs. Not only does  Strength increase the amount of Health restored, but you don't need to worry about timing it like you would with Vulnerable.
Reaper is an excellent utility for self-damaging decks, especially ones with Rupture. It gives you more health in mid-battle, allowing the usually short-lived deck to effectively fight longer battles against bosses.
Consider combining it with Dual Wield or Double Tap to maximize its potential.
 Strange Spoon can be a double-edged sword - more plays means more HP, but the card's utility generally decreases with the number of enemies and less empty health to heal.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Interactions' of Rupture?

Aside from cards that cause the player to lose HP immediately when played (such as Bloodletting), other card-related effects trigger Rupture as well:
Pain triggers Rupture every time the player plays a card while Pain is in hand.
Burn and Decay trigger Rupture if any damage from them is unblocked.
Losing HP from Regret also triggers Rupture.
Pain triggers Rupture every time the player plays a card while Pain is in hand.
Burn and Decay trigger Rupture if any damage from them is unblocked.
Losing HP from Regret also triggers Rupture.
The amount of HP lost does not affect the amount of Strength gained; losing 2 HP from Hemokinesis and losing 3 HP from Bloodletting will both only trigger the Strength gain a single time. It is the number of instances of HP loss that affects how much Strength is gained.
However, multiple copies of Rupture stack as expected, granted more Strength each time a card causes the player to lose HP.
However, multiple copies of Rupture stack as expected, granted more Strength each time a card causes the player to lose HP.
Brutality and Combust work extremely well with Rupture, as they automatically trigger its effect every turn. Keep in mind that stacking multiple Brutalities or Combusts will not cause Rupture to trigger extra times (as stacking these cards simply increases the amount of HP lost at once). will not trigger a single Rupture multiple times. However, multiple Ruptures will stack, and be triggered by Brutality or Combust.
J.A.X. is an excellent card to use with Rupture, getting even more Strength mileage out of the HP loss.
If HP loss is prevented by Tungsten Rod or Buffer, no Strength is gained.
Damaging effects that are indirectly triggered by cards, such as Thorns, Sharp Hide, and Beat of Death, will not activate Rupture..

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Spot Weakness?

Although the  Runic Dome hides enemy intents, this card can help reveal if the enemy is attacking this turn, as it will either fail if they are not, or it will grant the player  Strength. This is useful against non-deterministic enemies like Thieves, but it can also lead to a waste of Energy.
The Strength gained from Spot Weakness is repeatable and lasts for the rest of the battle, which makes it an excellent enabler for Limit Break.
The Strength bonus is more effective when combined with multi-attack cards like Sword Boomerang, Heavy Blade or Pummel.
Spot Weakness is a strong utility card for defensive  Block-heavy decks. It sets up future power turns while the player defends against incoming attacks.
The card is more reliable than it initially appears, since most enemy turns are attacks. The times when it's inactive are also the turns that it's least useful - if the enemy doesn't intend to attack, the player can go all-out with attacks instead of playing defensive cards.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of Acrobatics?

Acrobatics costs 1 energy to draw 3 cards and discard 1 card, thus yielding a net gain of 2 cards (not considering the cost of drawing acrobatics in the first place). Although on the surface it may seem to be no better than a card like Backflip, it synergizes very well with cards whose effects trigger upon being discarded (e.g. Tactician, Reflex), or who have additional effects if other cards have been discarded (e.g. Sneaky Strike, Eviscerate). It also allows you discard Curses, Statuses, or cards that aren't useful on a given turn.
The upgrade for Acrobatics is relatively powerful, as it provides a net gain of 3 cards instead of 2. In addition to the obvious benefits of additional card draw, this also means that you have more options for cards to discard.
The upgrade for Acrobatics is relatively powerful, as it provides a net gain of 3 cards instead of 2. In addition to the obvious benefits of additional card draw, this also means that you have more options for cards to discard.
In general, drawing 3 cards sounds very meritable, but this is usually only true in the later part of the game. Early on, when you only have 3 Energy, it is rarely reasonable to spend 1 energy purely to draw cards, since you still need energy to play the cards that you draw.
Reusable cards that provide energy can help improve the effectiveness of Acrobatics early on. For instance, Concentrate (especially when both it and Acrobatics are upgraded) becomes more viable when you have the additional cards drawn by Acrobatics.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:

The After Image buff is stackable, so playing multiple copies of After Image will provide even more Block per card. Since After Image+ only costs 1 Energy and is Innate, playing more than 1 copy on the first turn is easily done.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Tips' of After Image?

After Image is helpful for countering the Corrupt Heart's Beat of Death status, which inflicts 1 damage immediately after the player plays a card.
This card is an excellent addition to any Shiv-based deck, as every individual Shiv grants 1 Block.
Playing many cards in a turn (e.g. with Shivs) is liable to generate excess Block, so Blur can be used to carry it over to the next turn.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat All-Out Attack?

All-Out Attack is a strong source of upfront AoE (Area-of-Effect) damage. It has higher burst of damage than Dagger Spray, upgraded or otherwise. It scales with  Strength worse than the latter, given that All-Out Attack hits only once. However, due to the same reason, it is less punishing to use against enemies with  Thorns.

With its discard being random in nature, it is highly preferable to use all the other high-impact cards before using this card as a sort of 'closer' card to make it less likely that it will discard a card that you actually wanted to play.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is the strategy to defeat Bullet Time?

Taking full advantage of Bullet Time requires more thought and effort than it might seem at first. The key thing to remember is that Bullet Time itself takes up a slot in any hand you draw it into, and does nothing but let you play the remaining cards. Furthermore, unlike with generic energy-gain cards, cards that draw other cards must be played before Bullet Time itself.
If you're just drawing five cards a turn, Bullet Time will let you play four of them; if you already have an Energy relic, and most of your cards cost 1 or 0, Bullet Time will be completely useless (no better than a Curse) every time it's drawn. For it to be useful, the total cost of the other cards worth playing in your hand has to be higher than your Energy limit. In a normal deck that hasn't been intentionally built around it, this happens less frequently than you would expect.
Alternatively, instead of running a high-cost deck, you must at least ensure you have enough card-draw effects that you can use before Bullet Time consistently, specifically Acrobatics or Backflip. This requires 4 Energy or Bullet Time+. Other draws such as Prepared or Tools of the Trade aren't necessarily sufficient, since they don't give a net positive in the amount of cards you get. Escape Plan only replaces itself and may grant some  Block, but does not increase the number of cards in your hand.
Alternatively, instead of running a high-cost deck, you must at least ensure you have enough card-draw effects that you can use before Bullet Time consistently, specifically Acrobatics or Backflip. This requires 4 Energy or Bullet Time+. Other draws such as Prepared or Tools of the Trade aren't necessarily sufficient, since they don't give a net positive in the amount of cards you get. Escape Plan only replaces itself and may grant some  Block, but does not increase the number of cards in your hand.
As a result of this, the decks that want Bullet Time are ones with lots of high-cost cards and few cards that cost 0 or even 1. It's also more valuable if you've made it to the late game and still haven't found any suitable Energy relics, forcing you to accomplish as much as you can with your starting 3.
Curses and Statuses can weaken Bullet Time further; any deck that uses it is going to be vulnerable to them.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is 'Synergies' of Bullet Time?

Bullet Time is extremely useful with the  Snecko Eye, since the extra draw and random costs increase the chance that it will let you play more than you could have otherwise. It also provides a degree of protection from bad cost rolls, since you'll always be able to play Bullet Time if you draw it, thereby enabling you to play all the other cards in your hand. The Snecko Eye will often reduce Bullet Time's cost below 3 Energy as well, meaning that there may still be spare Energy for drawing more cards before using Bullet Time.
Since Bullet Time makes all Attacks cost 0, the  Wrist Blade will make them stronger.
The  Runic Pyramid can keep cards that weren't played during a turn to fill up a hand to play with Bullet Time.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:
What is Burst in Slay the Spire?

Burst is a Skill card for The Silent . It plays the next Skill card this turn a second time, for no Energy . As a Rare card, it can be obtained after defeating a Boss . It is The Silent's version of Double Tap and Amplify . Upon upgrade, it will trigger again on the 2nd Skill card played in the same turn. The second play is NOT added to your draw or discard pile. The scaling buff from Burst (and also from Double Tap and Amplify ) is the number of cards that will be played twice, not the number of times the card will be played. This means playing multiple Bursts will add to the number of skills that will be played twice that turn, not make the next skill play 3 or more times.

Answer the question about Slay the Spire:

The second play will not cost any Energy, but it will trigger any other consequences of playing the card. For example, a Bursted J.A.X. will trigger the self-damage twice.
The second play of a card that costs X energy will use the same value of X as the first.
The second play acts as a separate card. This has interactions including, but not limited to:
 Ink Bottle,  Letter Opener: Both plays count towards playing skills for their benefits.
 Velvet Choker: Both plays count towards the amount of cards played for the turn.
Time Eater's  Time Warp power: Both plays increase the counter as usual. If the second skill is the 13th action on his counter, it will NOT occur, unlike  Velvet Choker.
